content.description: This one is a LINE. The high prow at the center of the first "madrone cove". Water streak/rib feature with sweet pockets and body-English climbing low, exit the chimney to the right for wild moves on mostly good holds out front-side of the high prow, a brief bouldery crux. Continuously steep, airy position with a couple of dissapointingly good rests (would be mega enduro otherwise). Good rock quality starting after the first bolt. Start is fine without a stick clip Knee pad may be nice, mainly to save wear on your pants/skin. But certainly not cause you need even more rest!
content.location: Look for a water streak/rib feature that emanates from a chimney and adjacent arete 50 ft up. Waterbender climbs in the chimney and onto the left face of the prow. Airbender heads out the steep, right face of the prow

content.description: Start up the streak as for Airbender, passing two cruxy sections, both calling on a bit of pocket strength. Escape left just before the boulder crux of Airbender: climb into the chimney finishing on the back side of the prow for 3 bolts of steep but easy 3-d climbing. One 5.10-ish move heading right feels quite committing but is reasonably protected.
content.location: Climb airbender and then bail into the chimney.

content.description: Full name "The 40 year old swingers", this is actually two variations.A short route. Stick clip the first bolt and jump start or boulder your way up to a mossy slab with ample jugs. Two starts are possible, with separate first bolts. May be good but will require some industrial level moss removal.Probably WAY harder than 5.9, only one way to find out...
content.protection: 2ish bolts to chains. An alternate starting bolt to the left. Stainless and should be in good condition
content.location: The lower angle wall to the left of Swampbender.

content.description: The steepest 5.11 here. Well-featured route characterized by hand-heel matches and huge, gymnastic reaches. The difficulty is strongly height/reach dependent. manage the rope well when pulling the lip. two sections separated by a no hands on a pedestal to the leftstick clip the 2nd bolt, Best to start from the undercling to the left.. Bad rock at the bottom. Mostly climbs just left of the bolt line.Forest toproped a similar line years ago and called it 'bovine love'.
content.location: Around the corner, lookers left, from the other "benders". faces west. Look for a steep wave feature with pedestals to either side.

content.description: Start on the trunk of the nearly horizontal madrone growing out of the cliff base. Stick clip the first bolt, or climb gently through the initial moves on marginal (but heavily cleaned) rock to the ledge. Choose well from countless available pockets, or choose differently to make the route a lot harder. Finesse your way through the green band on less positive holds, step high and finish on jugs past the lip.
content.location: Just to the right of the approach trail to the crag. Stand on the horizontal madrone to start.

content.description: This is a lightly overhanging, juggy endeavour similar to Fondue or Fondon't, as pumpy but perhaps with a more straightforward crux. Should be really fun as it continues to clean up and smooth out. Huecos, thread-throughs, telephone jugs, knobs, pockets. As long as you're not completely off-route, the most fragile features have been cleaned and tested. The first and second clips are relatively easy, and then it heads up and slightly left on sustained jugs and pockets.Has a capping roof and seems to stay completely dry, even during or after heavy downpour.Take care while clipping the 2nd bolt, or use a stick clip.
content.protection: 5 glue in bolts to sport loweroffs.First bolt is oversized and highly visible polished stainless. The following bolts are smaller gague and spraypainted matte black.Take care while clipping the 2nd bolt, or use a stick clip.
content.location: In the last "cove" to the right before Piranha pockets and the R.I.P. 40 feet up from the main trail. Begins up very featured rock on the right side of the cove, clipping the first, oversized glue-in from a stem on a pedestal, up and slightly left from there.

content.description: Start with a VB traverse from the left to gain the ledge. Alternatively, do the direct V1to the ledge straight below the bolt line. From the ledge, make one move to clip the first bolt. Easy pockets and jugs on decent but soft rock bring you through the first lip to more solid rock. The mantle at the fifth bolt will be the crux for some. Clip the bolt to the left of the ledge before making the mantle. Fifteen feet of slab with just enough holds will bring you to the anchors.
content.location: The Lookout Point approach trail deposits you directly in front of Retirement Plan.

content.description: In case youre wondering what this is, Just left of sky bison is a line of 3 temporary bolts on the steep wall. Needs more cleaning, and the best line is probably 3-6 feet right of those bolts.Not reccomended in it's current state, but not trying to keep anyone off it either.
content.protection: 3 temporary bolts, plated steel hangers, single biners on each, one bolt anchor for now.
content.location: 30 feet left of sky bison, on the short steep wall.

content.description: The green arete just right of where the trail hits the wall. runout to the second bolt is not difficult climbing, but can also be stick clipped.
content.location: Look for a smooth green panel and arete with a capping roof.

content.description: Steep start leads to a very technical dead vert face and arete. Likely needs cleaning but all-time movement as reported by Forest. Will update once I get around to climbing it.
content.protection: SS mech bolts. may be hidden in new moss. probably still in good shape.
content.location: Up and left, round the back behind all the benders. The last good looking feature, behind the RIP as well.  probably 100m walk past airbender, faces NW

content.description: The longest route here. Three fun boulder problems of escalating difficulty separated by sit down rests.  Can be a little harder while hanging the draws on the final (crux) boulder. May place a small chain here. Closely bolted with mostly safe falls, but keep an attentive belay and be aware of the ledges. Still recommended.
content.location: Starts in the "cave" feature just left of Fondue and right of Airbender.

content.description: Steep and friendly swiss cheese pockets take you off the starting ledge. At the 5th bolt doing a long reach, stemming, or working the arete allow passage through the crux for people of various body types. Either you won't notice the crux or you'll be at a loss for how to proceed. Has a long draw to help with cleaning on the lower. I'm generally opposed to giving a route this crumbly and short 4 stars, but I also can't imagine 5.10 (in the willamette valley, big qualifier) getting much more fun than this. It's cleaned up pretty well actually.
content.location: Just left of where the trail hits the wall, look for an overhanging swath of honeycombed pockets and a pretty slash of green rock high and right.

content.description: The clean, ever-shaded, green-streaked panel.Easy approach climbing to a hard six move boulder with unique grips. High quality rock, movement, and aesthetics. Maybe the best of the 'roped boulders' here.Can only say with confidence that it's somewhere between V8 and V10. I didn't use the thin mono above the 2nd bolt, going left instead.The crux felt low percentage and required good (very cold and dry) conditions. I never got close unless I was also numbing out by the end. Has the kind of holds you hit dynamically but precisely, and then have little hope of readjusting on, compounding any errors or hesitation. Maybe for some could be easier than EOES, but for me felt harder, and also less tweaky. Similar angle to the RIP, but with more edgework than pockets, and almost zero endurance required. all the stars, with the obvious qualifier that it's a 20 foot sport route, do as you will...
content.protection: 4 glueins. 1 bolt anchor with a steel loweroff biner.Stick clip reccomended, can hang every draw from the ground.
content.location: Up the hill to the left, around the corner from the 'benders and the swingers. A small cave feature low and a green panel above lurking behind a switchback in the trail

content.description: The first walls you hit on the trail: all aspects and angles, in a pretty setting with good tree shade(they never managed to log this close to the rock), with routes from 20-85 feet long. Loads more potential. Not the best rock quality in the zone but dilligent cleaning reveals some fun movement.
